data.text:
The official website of Beijing Organising Committee for the 2022 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games is https://www.beijing2022.cn/en.

The full schedule can be found online at https://olympics.com/en/beijing-2022/schedule.

With a vision of “Joyful Rendezvous upon Pure Ice and Snow,” Beijing 2022 will build on the legacies of the landmark Beijing 2008 Olympic Games and expects to encourage millions of people across China to embrace winter sports.

The 109 events in seven Olympic winter sports will be held in the three competition zones of central Beijing, Yanqing and Zhangjiakou.

Beijing will host four snow events (snowboard big air and freestyle skiing big air, men’s and women’s), plus all the ice events (curling, ice hockey and skating), making use of the legacy venues of Beijing 2008.

Yanqing, a suburban district of Beijing (80 kilometers to the northwest) and home to the famous Badaling and Juyongguan stretches of the Great Wall, is to host the Alpine skiing and sliding (bobsled, skeleton and luge) events.

Zhangjiakou, farther to the northwest in the neighboring Hebei province, will host all the other snow events (snowboard, freestyle skiing, cross-country skiing, ski jumping, Nordic combined and biathlon) in its Chongli district, a popular skiing destination.

The addition of seven new events — women’s monobob, freestyle skiing big air (men’s and women’s), and mixed team events in short-track speedskating team relay, ski jumping, freestyle skiing aerials and snowboard cross — to Beijing 2022’s sports program will bring about the most gender-balanced Olympic Winter Games to date, with more female athletes (45%) and women’s events than at any previous games.

Both the opening ceremony on Friday, Feb. 4 and the closing ceremony on Sunday, Feb. 20 will be held at the National Stadium in Beijing (also known as the Bird’s Nest).

–

Alpine skiing

–

There are 11 events in the Alpine competition at the games, with 33 medals up for grabs. For men and women, there will be races in downhill, super-G, giant slalom, slalom and Alpine combined.

There will also be mixed team races. Teams are comprised of two men and two women representing the same nation. Two teams compete against each other in a parallel slalom race, with two skiers racing one another on the same course simultaneously, side-by-side. In this event whoever crosses the finish line first is the winner, meaning the team that wins three races advances to the next round of the competition. In the event that both teams win two races, the team with the lowest combined time of their fastest male and female athlete is the winner.

History: Men’s and women’s Alpine skiing both debuted on the Olympic program in 1936 at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany.

Venue: The Alpine competition will take place at the National Alpine Ski Centre in the Yanqing competition zone.

Schedule: Feb. 6-19

–

Biathlon

–

Biathlon combines the endurance and intensity of cross-country skiing with the precision and skill of rifle shooting.

The biathlon competition features 11 events: For men, there will be races for 10k sprint, 20k individual, 12.5k pursuit, 15k mass start and a 4×7.5k relay. For women, there will be races for 7.5k sprint, 15k individual, 10k pursuit, 12.5k mass start and 4x6k relay.

Additionally, there will be a 4x6k mixed relay with men and women.

History: Biathlon made its debut at the 1960 Winter Olympics in Squaw Valley, California.

Venue: Biathlon events will take place at the National Biathlon Center in the Zhangjiakou competition zone.

Schedule: Feb. 5-19

–

Bobsled

–

There are 12 medals available in the bobsled competition at the games.

For men, there will be two-man and four-man races. For women, there will be two-woman and monobob races.

History: Bobsledding has been featured at every Winter Olympics except the Olympic Winter Games in 1960 at Squaw Valley, California. In 1924 the sport made its Olympic debut with a four-man event at Chamonix, France. A two-man event was added in 1932 at Lake Placid. A two-woman event was added in 2002 at Salt Lake City. Women’s monobob is being added in Beijing.

Venue: All sliding events will take place at the Yanqing National Sliding Centre, located in the Xiaohaituo mountain area in Yanqing.

Schedule: Feb. 13-20

–

Cross-country skiing

–

There will be 12 cross-country skiing events in the competition in Beijing, with 36 medals to be won.

For men, there will be races for 15k classic, 15 15k skiathlon, sprint free, team sprint classic, 4x10k relay and 50k mass start free. For women, there will be races for 10k classic, 7.5 7.5k skiathlon, sprint free, team sprint classic, 4x5k relay and 30k mass start free.

History: Cross-country skiing has been a part of the Winter Olympic program for every games, beginning with the men’s 50k and 18k competitions in 1924 at Chamonix, France. A women’s event (the 10k) was first contested in 1952 at Oslo, Norway.

Venue: The cross-country skiing competition will take place at the National Cross-Country Centre in the Zhangjiakou cluster.

Schedule: Feb. 5-20

–

Curling

–

In curling, teams use brooms and specially designed shoes to slide granite stones across the ice towards a target.

With nine medals up for grabs, there will be 10 participating teams (four players per team in matches) in the men’s, women’s and mixed doubles (two athletes per team — one male, one female).

History: Men’s curling was a part of the Winter Olympics in 1924 at Chamonix, France, but it was later dropped in 1928 before being reintroduced as a demonstration sport in 1932 at Lake Placid. Curling remained an Olympic demonstration sport between 1936 and 1992 until it re-joined the Olympic program in 1998 at Nagano with men’s and women’s competitions. The mixed doubles competition was added in 2018 at Pyeongchang, South Korea.

Venue: Curling will take place at the Beijing National Aquatics Center, a.k.a. “The Water Cube.”

Schedule: Feb. 2-20

–

Figure skating

–

There are five events in the figure skating competition: men’s individual, women’s individual, pairs, ice dancing and the team event.

History: Figure skating is the oldest sport on the Olympic Winter Games program. It was contested at the 1908 London Games and again in 1920 in Antwerp. Men’s, women’s and pairs were the three events contested until 1972 at Sapporo, Japan. Ice dancing was added in 1976 at Innsbruck, Austria, and the mixed team debuted in 2014 at Sochi, Russia.

Venue: The figure skating competition will take place at the Capital Indoor Stadium in Beijing.

Schedule: Feb. 4-20

–

Freestyle skiing

–

There are 13 events in freestyle skiing: Men’s and women’s aerials, moguls, ski cross, halfpipe, slopestyle and big air. Plus there is an aerials mixed team event.

The aerials, halfpipe, slopestyle and moguls are all “judged” events — athletes receive a score from a group of judges based on the skill of their tricks and form they display on each of their runs in the competition. In the case of big air, competitors are also scored on the height and distance of each of their jumps.

Unlike the other freestyle skiing events, ski cross is a timed event rather than a judged one (the first athlete to cross the finish line wins).

History: Freestyle skiing debuted on the Olympic program in 1988 at Calgary, Canada, as a demonstration sport, with events for men and women in moguls, aerials and ballet. In 1992 at Albertville, France, the mogul event gained medal status, as did the aerial event in 1994 at Lillehammer, Norway. Ski cross debuted in 2010 at Vancouver, Canada. Slopestyle and halfpipe were added to the freestyle skiing program in 2014 at Sochi, Russia.

Venue: Freestyle skiing events will take place at two venues: the Genting Snow Park, located in the east of Chongli County of Zhangjiakou, and Shougang Park.

Schedule: Feb. 5-14

–

Ice hockey

–

There are only two events in the ice hockey competition, one for men and one for women.

The men’s tournament consists of 12 teams split into three groups: Group A — Canada, USA, Germany, China; Group B — ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark; and Group C — Finland, Sweden, Slovakia, Latvia.

The women’s tournament will feature 10 teams split between two groups: Group A — USA, Canada, Finland, ROC (Russian Olympic Committee), Switzerland; and Group B — Japan, China, Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden.

History: The first Olympic ice hockey tournament took place at the 1920 Summer Olympics in Antwerp, Belgium, with a men’s competition. The sport was moved to the inaugural Winter Olympics program in 1924 at Chamonix, France. A women’s tournament was added in 1998 at Nagano Games.

Venue: The Wukesong Sports Centre and National Indoor Stadium will share hosting duties for the ice hockey competitions at Beijing.

Schedule: Feb. 3-20

–

Luge

–

Luge is known as the fastest of the three sliding sports at the Winter Olympics, which includes bobsled and skeleton.

There are 12 medals available in four luge events: men’s singles, men’s doubles, women’s singles and team relay.

History: Luge made its Olympic debut in 1964 at Innsbruck, Austria. The team relay event was added in 2014 at Sochi, Russia.

Venue: All sliding events will take place at the Yanqing National Sliding Centre, located in the Xiaohaituo mountain area in Yanqing.

Schedule: Feb. 5-10

–

Nordic combined

–

Nordic combined is made up of two separate sports: ski jumping and cross-country skiing.

The Nordic combined competition will feature three events: men’s individual Gundersen normal hill/10k; men’s individual Gundersen large hill/10k; and men’s team Gundersen large hill/4x5k.

All three Nordic combined events consist of a ski jumping competition and a cross-country skiing race.

History: In 1924, Nordic combined was introduced to the Olympic program at the first Winter Games in Chamonix, France — where it has remained ever since, but only for men. It is the only Olympic sport not open to women.

Venue: The Nordic combined competition will take place at two venues in the Zhangjiakou cluster. The National Ski Jumping Centre will host the ski jumping portion of the competition, and the National Cross-Country Centre will host the cross-country element.

Schedule: Feb. 9-17

–

Skeleton

–

In skeleton, competitors ride head-first and prone on a sledge down an icy track at high speed.

With six medals up for grabs, the skeleton competition features two events: men’s singles and women’s singles.

History: Men’s skeleton was introduced on the Olympic program in 1928 at St. Moritz, Switzerland, and then again in 1948, also at St. Moritz. It was reintroduced as a men’s and women’s event in 2002 at Salt Lake City and has remained a part of the Olympic program ever since.

Venue: All sliding events will take place at the Yanqing National Sliding Centre, located in the Xiaohaituo mountain area in Yanqing.

Schedule: Feb. 10-12

–

Ski jumping

–

There will be five events in ski jumping at Beijing: men’s normal hill individual, men’s large hill individual, men’s team, women’s normal hill individual and mixed team.

In competition, jumps are evaluated by the distance traveled and the style of the jump. The distance is measured along the curve of the landing hill from the takeoff point to the spot where the jumper lands.

History: Ski jumping has been a part of the Winter Olympic program since the first games in 1924 at Chamonix. France, when the men’s large hill was the sole event. A normal hill competition was added in 1964 at Innsbruck, Austria, with the men’s team large hill joining the program in 1988 at Calgary, Canada. The women’s competition was added in 2014 at Sochi, Russia, and the mixed team event will debut in 2022 at Beijing.

Venue: The ski jumping competition will take place at the National Ski Jumping Centre in the Zhangjiakou cluster.

Schedule: Feb. 5-14

–

Snowboarding

–

There are 11 events in the snowboard competition at Beijing: the mixed team snowboard cross for men and women, the parallel giant slalom, snowboard cross, halfpipe, slopestyle and big air.

The halfpipe, slopestyle and big air competitions are all judged events, meaning each athlete’s run(s) are scored by a panel of judges who evaluate riders based on the difficulty of the tricks, execution of the run, amplitude of the techniques and landing of the jumps. The snowboard cross, parallel giant slalom and mixed team snowboard cross events are all races (first to cross the line wins).

History: Snowboarding made its Winter Olympic debut in 1998 at Nagano, Japan. Men’s and women’s events were contested in the giant slalom and halfpipe competitions, and at in 2002 at Salt Lake City, parallel giant slalom and halfpipe were added. Snowboard cross made its debut in 2006 at Turin, Italy, with slopestyle and parallel slalom added in 2014 at Sochi, Russia. Big air made its debut in 2018 at Pyeongchang, South Korea. Mixed team snowboard cross will debut in 2022 at Beijing.

Venue: The snowboard competition will take place at Genting Snow Park in the Zhangjiakou cluster.

Schedule: Feb. 5-15

–

Speedskating

–

Speedskating will feature a total of 14 events at the Winter Olympics — seven for men and seven for women.

For men, there will be races for the 500m, 1,000m, 1,500m, 5,000m, 10,000m, mass start and team pursuit.

For women, there will be races for the 500m, 1,000m, 1,500m, 3,000m, 5,000m, mass start and team pursuit.

History: Speedskating made its Olympic debut at the inaugural Winter Games in 1924 at Chamonix, France. However, women were only authorized to compete in the discipline in 1932 at Lake Placid, which was then only a demonstration sport. Women’s speedskating was officially included in the Olympic program in 1960 at Squaw Valley, California.

Venue: All speedskating events will take place at the National Speed Skating Oval (also known as the Ice Ribbon).

Schedule: Feb. 5-19

–

Speedskating: Short-track

–

Short-track speedskating will feature a total of nine events at the Winter Olympics: four for men, four for women and one mixed team event.

For men the races will be for the 500m, 1,000m, 1,500m and the 5,000m team relay.

For women, there will be races for the 500m, 1,000m, 1,500m and the 3000m team relay.

History: Short-track speedskating was added to the Olympic program in 1992 at Albertville, France, with two individual events and two relays. Since the 2006 Olympic Winter Games in Turin, Italy, the program has included eight events and will expand to nine with the addition of the mixed team relay in 2022.

Venue: All short-track speedskating events will take place at the Capital Indoor Stadium.

Schedule: Feb. 5-16
